info.abstract: The Curriculum Pacing component allows users to visualize and explore end-to-end curriculum data. To see what Curriculum Pacing is and what does it look like, please refer to this paper. To get more insight into the parameters of the component, please refer to this paper. In a nutshell, using this component, you will be able to see how students progress through the curriculum or problem hierarchy over time.
info.description: Curriculum Pacing is a way to visualize student learning trajectories through curriculum units and sections. This visualization is suitable to quickly explore end-to-end curriculum data and see patterns of student learning. Try creating this visualization for different sub-samples of the data having different properties and it might reveal differences in student learning paths in the different cohorts.

ul.li: Input 1 - student-problem: This input is either data in the DataShop student-problem format or any TSV dataset with these columns: Anon Student Id (String), Problem Hierarchy (String), Problem Start Time (ISO Timestamp), Corrects (Number), Incorrects (Number)

Input 2 (optional) - hierarchy-order: This optional input is a CSV file that gives the correct linear order of the values in the Problem Hierarchy column. This is a two column CSV file with these two column names: Problem Hierarchy (String), Problem Hierarchy Order (Number)
PlotType - (1) Usage - Just show student usage over time (2) Usage and performance - Show both student usage and performance over time

RelMinTimeUnit -- Integer, applies only to relative time scale. Used to filter the X axis of the plot. Sets the minimum time unit. For example, if time scale is relative, and time scale resolution is week, min time unit = 5 will start all students at their 5th week of usage.
RelMaxTimeUnit -- Integer, similar to RelMinTimeUnit, sets maximum X axis limit.
AbsMinTimeUnit -- ISO Timestamp, applies only to absolute time scale. Used to filter X axis of the plot. Sets the minimum time.
AbsMaxTimeUnit -- ISO Timestamp, similar to AbsMaxTimeUnit, sets maximum X axis limit.
